newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - FX vols stagnant as dlr stalls near highs.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - FX vols stagnant as dlr stalls near highs.

text.p: Implied volatilities for dollar-pair options were stagnant in U.S. trading as the greenback's early rally fizzled out a little short of recent highs, dealers said.

"Everyone is basically dollar-bullish, but there's so much concern about political factors that they can't keep on buying at the higher end," said Kyoko Hiramatsu, a senior dealer at Bank of Yokohama in New York. "There's so much temptation to take profit."
The dollar was circling the 127-yen area in mid-afternoon U.S. trading, just below its mid-April high near 127.20.
One-month dollar/yen implied volatility stood at 8.5/8.7 percent, up 0.1 point from late Tuesday. Risk reversals, the put/call pricing differential, were steady at around par.

Traders said one of the dampers on volatilities was a huge reverse knock-out option -- some $2.5 billion worth, according to some accounts -- with a barrier price of around 127.40 yen that expires on Thursday. Such exotic options tend to supply gamma to the interbank community and prompt selling in short-dated options.
"There seems to be a lot of long-gamma positions out there," said a U.S. bank trader in California.
The California trader noted, however, that the exotic option's expiration at 1000 EDT/1400 GMT on Thursday could remove the downward pressure and lead to a spike up in dollar/yen.
That was a distinct possibility, particularly with the April U.S. employment report due out Friday, agreed Hiramatsu at Bank of Yokohama.
"People who had been selling the dollar to defend the trigger level could start buying back," she added.
Dollar/mark volatilities were flat as the dollar was stayed below Monday's 37-month high of 1.7389 marks.
One-month dollar/mark volatility was pegged at 8.4/8.6 percent, virtually unchanged. Risk reversals were also steady, with one-month 25-delta 0.1/0.4 point skewed toward mark puts.
Elsewhere, sterling volatilities looked hapless despite Thursday's U.K. general elections.
"One-week is better bid than a few days ago, of course, but 8-1/4 percent is not what you would consider a very firm volatility for a country that's going into elections," the California trader said.
One-week cable volatility stood at 7.7/8.7 percent and one-month at 7.4/7.7, both marginally above Tuesday's levels.

"Cable (spot) yesterday went up to $1.6330 and this morning we came down to $1.6185, so that's giving us something like 12-percent in intraday volatility," he said, adding that he thought cable options looked undervalued.
He also noted that the $1.62-area had proved to be a strong support level for sterling and a declining trendline came in in the lower-$1.63 area.
"We're forming some kind of a triangle in technicals," he said. "We could see some action if Labor actually wins (in the elections)."
